title: Introduction to Go
description: Learn the basic concepts and objectives of Go
content:
Go (also known as Weiqi in Chinese and Baduk in Korean) is one of the oldest board games still played today, originating in China over 4,000 years ago.

# The Objective
The goal of Go is to control more territory than your opponent by the end of the game.

# The Equipment
* The board: A grid of 19x19 lines (beginners often start with 9x9 or 13x13)
* Black and white stones: Black plays first
* Simple rules that lead to infinite complexity

# Why Learn Go?
* Develops strategic thinking
* Improves pattern recognition
* Enhances concentration and patience
* Connects you with thousands of years of culture

exercises.question: What is the main objective of Go?
exercises.answer: To control more territory than your opponent

title: Placing Stones and Liberties
description: Understand how stones are placed and what liberties are
content:
# Placing Stones
Players take turns placing stones on the intersections (not in the squares) of the board. Once placed, stones don't move.

# Liberties
Liberties are the empty points directly adjacent to a stone or group of stones (not diagonally).

* A stone in the middle of the board has 4 liberties
* A stone on the edge has 3 liberties
* A stone in the corner has 2 liberties

# Connected Groups
Stones of the same color that are adjacent (not diagonally) form a group and share their liberties.

# Life and Death
When a group loses all its liberties, it is captured and removed from the board.

title: Capturing Stones
description: Learn how to capture opponent stones
content:
# Basic Capture
You capture enemy stones by removing all their liberties. Captured stones are removed from the board and kept as prisoners.

# Capture Rules
* Fill all liberties of an enemy group to capture it
* Captured stones count as points (in Japanese rules)
* Multiple groups can be captured in one move

# Self-Capture (Suicide)
You cannot place a stone that would have no liberties, unless that move captures enemy stones.

# Practice
Try to identify groups that can be captured in one move (this is called 'atari').

exercises.description: Find the move that captures white stones

title: The Ko Rule
description: Understanding the ko rule and why it exists
content:
# What is Ko?
'Ko' means 'eternity' in Japanese. It's a situation where players could capture and recapture the same stone forever.

# The Ko Rule
You cannot immediately recapture a stone that just captured your stone if it would recreate the previous board position.

# Ko Fights
* You must play elsewhere first (a 'ko threat')
* If your opponent responds to your threat, you can recapture
* Ko fights are some of the most exciting moments in Go!

# Types of Ko
* Simple ko: The basic back-and-forth capture
* Complex ko: Multiple ko situations
* Ko threats: Moves that demand a response

title: Territory and Eyes
description: Learn about territory and the concept of eyes
content:
# Territory
Territory is the empty space you surround and control. At the end of the game, you count your territory plus captured stones.

# Eyes
An 'eye' is an empty point surrounded by your stones. A group with two separate eyes can never be captured - it's 'alive'.

# Two Eyes Live
* A group needs two separate eyes to be unconditionally alive
* One eye is not enough - the opponent can fill it
* False eyes don't count (when the surrounding stones can be captured)

# Making Territory
* Build walls to enclose space
* Corner territory is easiest to make
* Side territory is next
* Center territory is hardest

exercises.description: Identify which groups have two eyes
